journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Is Magnetic Resonance Imaging Reliable in Predicting Clinical Outcome After Articular Cartilage Repair of the Knee?
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

author-notes.corresp: #Daniel B.F. Saris, MD, PhD, Department of Orthopaedics, University Medical Center Utrecht, POB 85500, 3508 GA, Utrecht, the Netherlands (e-mail: d.saris@umcutrecht.nl).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: While MRI can provide a detailed morphological evaluation after articular cartilage repair, its additional value in determining clinical outcome has yet to be determined.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To evaluate the correlation between MRI and clinical outcome after cartilage repair and to identify parameters that are most important in determining clinical outcome.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A systematic search was performed in Embase, MEDLINE, and the Cochrane Collaboration. Articles were screened for relevance and appraised for quality. Guidelines in the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis (PRISMA) Statement were used. Chi-square tests were performed to find variables that could determine correlation between clinical and radiological parameters.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: A total of 32 articles (total number of patients, 1019) were included. A majority (81%) were case series or cohort studies that used similar standardized MRI techniques. The mean Coleman score was 63 (range, 42-96). For the majority of MRI parameters, limited or no correlation was found. Nine studies (28%) found a correlation between clinical outcome and the composite magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART) or Henderson score and 7 (22%) with defect fill. In 5 studies, a weak to moderate correlation was found between clinical outcome and the T2 index (mean Pearson coefficient r = .53).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Strong evidence to determine whether morphological MRI is reliable in predicting clinical outcome after cartilage repair is lacking. Future research aiming specifically at clinical sensitivity of advanced morphological and biochemical MRI techniques after articular cartilage repair could be of great importance to the field.

kwd-group.kwd: magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART)

body.p: The repair of articular cartilage defects of the knee has rapidly developed and is now considered standard of care in orthopaedics worldwide. This has created an increasing need for reliable structural outcome tools. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is currently considered the gold standard for structural evaluation of cartilage defects and repair.8 Knee protocols with standard 2-dimensional sequences as well as more advanced isotropic 3-dimensional (3D) MRI can provide a detailed morphological evaluation, whereas techniques such as T1rho, T2 mapping, and delayed gadolinium-enhanced MRI of cartilage (dGEMRIC) are increasingly being used for biochemical analysis. These noninvasive measures are promising in that they have the potential to replace more invasive resources such as arthroscopy and biopsy. However, the debate in the literature regarding the correlation between radiological and clinical outcome is a cause for concern.5,24,26,37,45,55 Indeed, Salzmann et al recently reported poor correlation between clinical and MRI outcomes at 10 years, as 5 patients had a poor magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART) score while achieving satisfactory clinical improvement after autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI) (Salzmann GM, Porichis S, Ghanem N, et al, unpublished data, International Cartilage Repair Society [ICRS] World Congress, May 2012, Montreal, Canada). Conversely, Dhollander et al11 demonstrated intact repair tissues in patients with persistent symptoms after treatment with an osteochondral plug. These findings are remarkable as the MOCART score is accepted as a reliable score for assessing cartilage repair with good interobserver agreement.37 Thus, although MRI can provide a detailed morphological assessment, its additional value in determining clinical outcome has yet to be determined. Therefore, the aim of this systematic review was to evaluate the correlation between MRI and clinical outcome after cartilage repair and identify parameters that are most important in determining clinical outcome.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A systematic review of the literature was performed on MRI assessment after articular cartilage repair of the knee. Data from individual articles were compiled to determine the correlation between MRI assessment and clinical outcome. The search was conducted on June 13, 2012, in the electronic databases of MEDLINE, Embase, and the Cochrane Collaboration using the following parameters: (cartilage repair) OR (cartilage restoration) OR (autologous chondrocyte implantation) OR (autologous chondrocyte transplantation) OR (matrix-assisted autologous chondrocyte transplantation) OR (matrix-induced autologous chondrocyte implantation) OR (MACT) OR (MACI) OR (characterized chondrocyte implantation) OR (autologous osteochondral transplantation) OR (osteochondral autologous transplantation) OR (OATS) OR (osteochondral autograft transplantation) OR (OCT) OR (mosaicplasty) OR (allograft osteochondral transplantation) OR (microfracture) OR (microfracturing) AND (magnetic resonance imaging) OR (MRI) OR (delayed gadolinium enhanced) OR (dGEMRIC) OR (T2 mapping) OR (T2 index) OR (radiologic) OR (radiological) OR (radiographic).

The articles were screened by title and abstract. The following inclusion criteria for relevant articles were used during the initial screening of titles and abstracts: therapeutic or diagnostic studies of articular cartilage repair with a minimal follow-up of 12 months and clinical as well as MRI assessment. Languages included were English, German, and Dutch. Exclusion criteria were etiologic studies, reviews and case reports, animal and cadaver studies, degenerative or osteoarthritic defects, and full texts not retrievable. The remaining articles were appraised by 2 separate observers (TSdW and GHW). The Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions25 and the guidelines for Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis (PRISMA)42 were used. A quality assessment was performed for each individual study with focus on selection bias (patient selection and homogeneity), attrition bias (analysis based on the availability of MRI), detection bias (blinding and independence of MRI observer(s)), and reporting bias (selective reporting of correlation results). The modified Coleman Methodology score was used to assess the overall risk of bias.7 Extracted data from the selected studies included patient demographics, surgical procedure(s), MRI techniques and scores, defect sizes, and clinical outcome scores along with correlation statistics. To perform a meta-analysis, data were generated based on either the presence or absence of correlation between the different MRI parameters and the overall clinical outcome scores. Chi-square tests were used to examine which of the following variables could determine correlation between clinical and radiological outcome: level of evidence, Coleman score, study size, follow-up period, patient age, defect size, and type of clinical outcome score. Correlation analyses that were not performed or Pearson coefficients that could not be obtained were classified as not applicable (NA).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The literature search in MEDLINE resulted in 586 articles. The search in Embase and Cochrane resulted in 902 and 42 articles, respectively. After excluding 314 duplicates, 1216 articles remained for screening title and abstract. After application of the inclusion and exclusion criteria, 32 articles could be included (Figure 1, Table 1). A majority (81%) were therapeutic prospective case series or cohort studies that used similar standardized MRI techniques such as spin echoes (SEs), fast SE sequences, and 3D-gradient echo sequences. The overall risk of bias was moderate to high with a mean Coleman score of 62.8 (range, 42-96). Selection bias could not be ruled out for most studies because of insufficient explanation of the patient selection procedure and/or inclusion rate. The same holds true for detection and reporting bias, as ≥50% of the studies did not use independent MRI observers and/or provide exact correlation results (Table 2). Of all the studies, 3 applied an additional 3D double-echo steady-state sequence, and 5 studies performed T2 mapping. Most studies (72%) used the MOCART score with weighting and scoring as previously described,38,59 5 studies used the Henderson classification,24 and 4 articles applied a surgeon-specific score (Table 1). Tetta et al57 used a modified version of the MOCART score excluding the parameter of integrity of the subchondral lamina as it was part of the osteochondral graft. In assessing patients after allogenic chondrocyte implantation, Dhollander et al10 gave 3 times more weight to degree of filling, surface of the repair tissue, subchondral lamina, and subchondral bone and doubled the weight of the integration to the border zone. Clinical outcome scores that were used included the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score23 (41%), the Lysholm Knee Scoring Scale29,35 (25%), and the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS)3,49 (19%). The Brittberg,4 Cincinnati,39 visual analog scale (VAS),18 and Short Form–36 score40 were applied in a minority of studies (Table 1). To determine the correlation between clinical and radiological outcome, Takahashi et al55 used the Kruskal-Wallis H test and Tetta et al57 performed the Kendall τ correlation. All other studies used the Spearman rank coefficient. Six level 1b to 2b (Coleman score range, 78-96) and 26 level 3b to 4 (Coleman score range, 24-72) studies were included, respectively.14,32,33,52,66,68 From the 32 articles, 15 (overall n = 542) reported a correlation between several MRI parameters and clinical outcome, and 17 (overall n = 477 patients) did not. Nine studies (28%) reported a correlation between the composite MRI score and clinical outcome, and 7 (22%) reported a correlation with defect fill. For the majority of MRI parameters, limited or no correlation was found. In 5 studies, a weak to moderate correlation was demonstrated between either the IKDC or Lysholm score and the T2 index (mean Pearson correlation coefficient r = .53; range, .31-.74).13,17,34,50,64 Three of these 5 studies found this relation to be significant (P < .05).13,34,50 Table 3 presents the Pearson correlation coefficients for correlation between MRI parameters and clinical outcome, including their statistical significance. If exact coefficients were not provided, the presence (+) or absence (−) of correlation was marked in the table. Using chi-square tests, no variables could be identified that affect correlation between clinical and radiological outcome (P > .05).

caption.p: Flowchart of the literature search. FU, follow-up; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Standard knee protocol including spin echo (SE), fast SE sequences, and 3D-gradient echo sequences.

fn.label: a
fn.p: CS, case series; PCS, prospective cohort study; RCS, retrospective cohort study; RCT, randomized controlled trial.

fn.label: c

caption.p: Spearman Rank Correlations Between the MOCART, Henderson, and Proper Graft Scores With Clinical Outcome Scoresa

fn.label: a
fn.p: The numbers provided represent exact Pearson correlation coefficients; if no coefficients were given, (+) or (–) was used to indicate that articles found or did not find a correlation between radiological and clinical outcome, respectively. LOE, level of evidence; MOCART, magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue; NA, not applicable.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Despite the established use of MRI as a diagnostic tool for articular cartilage defects, its value in assessing patients after treatment has yet to be determined. This is underlined by the controversial relationship between clinical and radiological outcome found in the literature.5,24,26,37,45,55 As such, surgeons mainly rely on expertise when interpreting an MRI scan after cartilage repair.9 This systematic review sought to evaluate the correlation between MRI and clinical outcome after cartilage repair to elucidate the inconsistency in the literature and to identify parameters that are most important in determining clinical outcome. A systematic search of the MEDLINE, Embase, and Cochrane Collaboration databases resulted in a total of 32 studies after application of inclusion and exclusion criteria. Although the baseline characteristics, MRI sequences, and statistical methods were comparable between studies, there was a discrepancy in the use of outcome scores as well as a high frequency of detection (50%) and reporting bias (56%). Kreuz et al32,33 performed the only high-level (level 2b) studies that found a strong correlation between MRI parameters and the IKDC score after cartilage treatment. The 4 remaining randomized controlled trials did not find a correlation between clinical and radiological outcome.14,52,66,68 Perhaps more important, none of these high-level studies reported correlation between clinical and radiological outcome in their primary objectives. In fact, only 9 of the 32 included studies reported this correlation in their study objectives. The disagreement between studies and low methodological quality in cartilage repair have become apparent in recent years. In an analysis of the quality of cartilage repair studies, Jakobsen et al27 found methodological deficiencies with respect to the study type, inclusion and outcome criteria, rehabilitation protocol, and outcome assessment. This is corroborated by the heterogeneity found in our systematic review.

In a limited number of studies, the overall MRI and graft infill parameters were found to correlate most often with clinical outcome (Table 3). It could be that assessing a larger number of parameters on MRI disturbs its use in predicting clinical outcome. Indeed, Mithoefer et al41 looked specifically at defect filling and found a correlation with clinical outcome. Correspondingly, a consistent weak to moderate correlation was found in 5 studies that looked specifically at biochemical analysis (T2 mapping) and clinical outcome.13,17,34,50,64 Morphological MRI parameters such as T1, T2, and proton density contrasts have previously been reported to be less consistent and contingent on the maturity of the graft.55,58 Indeed, only 3 of the 32 studies found a correlation with signal intensity and clinical outcome.31-33 This holds the same for the subchondral bone and lamina, of which the clinical significance is unclear.31,43 Zanetti et al67 found bone marrow edema in osteoarthritic knees that could not be confirmed by histology. Others demonstrated clinical improvement in patients of whom a minority had an intact subchondral bone and lamina.12,31 Soder et al53 also found a high prevalence of bone marrow edema in asymptomatic soccer players. Conversely, an incomplete graft infill and the persistence of edema-like signals have been found to translate into inferior clinical outcome.5,21 The use of more detailed variables for the subchondral bone as included in the (3D) MOCART score may provide new insights into its clinical significance in the (near) future.65 Nevertheless, the true dimensions of the graft and blending into the subchondral bone may remain difficult to determine on MRI if not imaged in all 3 planes or disturbed by artifacts such as detached cartilage fragments or metallic abrasion particles.5,14 Again, the MOCART score, which is often compared with clinical outcome, was originally developed as a standardized evaluation tool for cartilage grafts and not clinical outcome.38 Indeed, it is not surprising that the weighting of the parameters of the MOCART has been altered by 2 of the included studies to improve its prognostic value.10,57

As MRI has drawbacks in terms of predictive value, second-look arthroscopy is still considered an important outcome measure. However, second-look arthroscopy may even have greater drawbacks, as it is invasive, does not allow for assessment of deeper structures (eg, the subchondral bone, “deep” osteophytes, and cysts), and shows limited correlation with clinical outcome. In a randomized controlled trial comparing ACI and microfracture, Knutsen et al28 found no correlation between histological findings after second-look arthroscopy and clinical outcome. In another randomized trial, biopsy specimens showed significantly better structural regeneration for ACI after 1 year, whereas similar clinical outcome was found for ACI and microfracture at 5 years.51,60 Gudas et al22 found no significant difference in clinical outcome between low (grade 1-2) and high (grade 3) ICRS macroscopic scores in a randomized trial comparing osteochondral autograft transfer system and microfracture. All things considered, it could be that the answer to identifying predictive morphological features and optimizing imaging techniques may not solely lie in the reparative tissue itself. Other factors currently not visible on MRI, such as inflammation, increased vascular penetration, and nerve growth, may also influence clinical outcome.1,2 Moreover, the complexity of the knee injury and patient history can make it difficult for any of the used outcome questionnaires to reflect the exact areas that are important to patients.6,48 Particularly for the IKDC, the score reflects an overall outcome of different items such as pain, activity, and function, which may confound correlation with MRI. However, when focusing specifically on pain, only 2 of 5 studies found a correlation between the MOCART score and VAS.10,37 Correspondingly, 2 of 7 found a correlation between the MRI score and the KOOS pain subscale.37,47

Limitations of this review are the variation in methodology, sample sizes, and cartilage repair and imaging techniques as well as the occurrence of (report) bias within the studies. The variation in follow-up duration could also be a limitation as the graft maturation process may differ between samples.20

In conclusion, to the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic review and meta-analysis to specifically aim at the correlation between clinical and radiological outcome. The most important finding of this review is that conclusive evidence to determine whether morphological MRI is reliable in predicting clinical outcome after cartilage repair is lacking. Although the MOCART score is a reliable cartilage graft evaluation tool, careful interpretation when using this score in relation to clinical outcome is warranted. Future research aiming specifically at clinical sensitivity of advanced morphological and biochemical MRI techniques after articular cartilage repair could be of great importance to the field.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.

An online CME course associated with this article is available for 1 AMA PRA Category 1 Credit™ at http://ajsm-cme.sagepub.com. In accordance with the standards of the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), it is the policy of The American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine that authors, editors, and planners disclose to the learners all financial relationships during the past 12 months with any commercial interest (A ‘commercial interest’ is any entity producing, marketing, re-selling, or distributing health care goods or services consumed by, or used on, patients). Any and all disclosures are provided in the online journal CME area which is provided to all participants before they actually take the CME activity. In accordance with AOSSM policy, authors, editors, and planners’ participation in this educational activity will be predicated upon timely submission and review of AOSSM disclosure. Noncompliance will result in an author/editor or planner to be stricken from participating in this CME activity.
